content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is one way you could implement the function `audi_filter` in Julia:
```
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter down to only the rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_audi = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)

    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows
    df_audi.audi_a4_type = true

    # Return the resulting DataFrame
    return df_audi
end
```

You can then call this function on your DataFrame `df_cars` like this:
```
filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

This will return a new DataFrame that contains only the rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro", and it will have an additional column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows.
